body: Tributes to David Levine, who died on Tuesday at 83, have been mulling over his place among today's cartoonists and caricaturists. Fair enough. But his genius was really that he wasn't like anybody else. Art Spiegelman used the word ''sobriety'' when we talked on Wednesday, and that's right. Mr. Levine brought sobriety back to caricature, among
title: AN APPRAISAL; Starting With Lines, but Ending With Truth

body: David Levine, whose macro-headed, somberly expressive, astringently probing and hardly ever flattering caricatures of intellectuals and athletes, politicians and potentates were the visual trademark of The New York Review of Books for nearly half a century, died Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 83 and lived in Brooklyn. His death, at New York
title: David Levine, Political Caricaturist With Wit and Bite, Is Dead at 83

body: The Municipal Art Society, a nonprofit membership organization founded in 1893, is perhaps best known for its successful fight to save Grand Central Terminal -- aided by the star power of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis -- and for helping to scuttle Mortimer B. Zuckerman's Columbus Circle towers by illustrating the mile-long shadow they would have cast
title: New Leader Seeks Stronger Voice For Art Society

body: MANY blocks in Midwood, with its rows of orderly detached homes and private driveways, give the feeling of a carefully planned suburb -- a serene surprise after turning off a thoroughfare like Coney Island Avenue or Ocean Parkway. But closer inspection reveals that the landscape has, in fact, been altered: on virtually every block, at least one or
title: LIVING IN | MIDWOOD, BROOKLYN; Where Prosperity Breeds Proximity

body: LEN CHENFELD is a bright, unimposing high school senior with the slightly spotty skin of a hormone-challenged teenager and the crystalline agenda of a Zen master: a Zen master addicted to basketball. On a recent Tuesday, he was icing his neck in preparation for two hours he lives for: basketball practice at Poly Prep Country Day School in Dyker
title: Len Chenfeld's Outside Shot

body: Rusty Kanokogi, considered the mother of women's judo after fighting for more than two decades to make it an Olympic sport, died Saturday in Brooklyn. She was 74. The cause was complications of multiple myeloma, a cancer of the plasma cells, her daughter, Jean, said. Kanokogi's battle for equality in judo began in 1959, when she and her club
title: Rusty Kanokogi, 74, Women's Judo Advocate

body: Day after day, night after night, Francisco Hernandez Jr. rode the subway. He had a MetroCard, $10 in his pocket and a book bag on his lap. As the human tide flowed and ebbed around him, he sat impassively, a gangly 13-year-old boy in glasses and a red hoodie, speaking to no one. After getting in trouble in class in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, and
title: Scared and Silent, Runaway, 13, Spent 11 Days in the Subways

body: Rusty Kanokogi, considered the mother of women's judo after fighting for more than two decades to make it an Olympic sport, died Saturday at Lutheran Medical Center in Brooklyn. She was 74. title: Rusty Kanokogi, Fiery Advocate for Women's Judo, Dies at 74

body: Were the women in ''On the Town'' always so brazen? Two are voraciously man-hungry, and the third is a cooch dancer -- but only to pay for her singing lessons. title: THEATER REVIEW | NEW JERSEY; Sailors and Mates, at Liberty

body: Wally Backman returned to the embrace of Major League Baseball after a five-year exile Monday when the Mets appointed him the manager of the Class A Brooklyn Cyclones. He will be introduced at a news conference Tuesday at KeySpan Park in Coney Island, less than 25 miles from where, as the feisty second baseman on the 1986 World Series championship
title: Backman and the Mets, Together Again

body: THE house that Michael and Lori Hiller planned to buy in South Park Slope, Brooklyn, was a good size for the neighborhood, and on a pleasant block. But then a problem developed with the building's certificate of occupancy. Since Mrs. Hiller had been the bigger fan of Park Slope, it was Mr. Hiller who had more zest for a new search. He found himself
title: LIVING IN | DITMAS PARK, BROOKLYN; Moved for the Space; Stayed for the Food

body: A JUGGLER on a unicycle wobbles past a cluster of clubgoers, deftly avoiding a collision that might spill their candy-color cocktails down the front of premium-label jeans. A clown on stilts hobbles past a table full of neatly coiffed men with untucked dress shirts who don't even look up from their drinks. It's hard enough to project an air of
title: BOîTE; Never Too Old To Act Young

body: After a year of ultimatums, threats and stop-and-go talks, the Bloomberg administration has agreed to pay $95.6 million to a developer for seven acres in the heart of Coney Island, according to executives on both sides of the negotiations. It is a crucial step forward for the city's vision of turning the faded and mostly dormant seaside amusement
title: Deal Raises Hopes for a Coney Island Revival

body: New York City for a Teenage Visitor Do you have any ideas for entertaining teenage visitors in New York City? body: It's longer than its Parisian counterpart (and closer to Yankee Stadium), lacks a Napoleonic triumphal arch and, thank goodness, never suffered the tramp of Nazi boots. But the Grand Concourse and Boulevard, celebrating its 100th year of traffic with a show at the Bronx Museum of the Arts, is often called the Bronx's Avenue des Champs-Élysées.
title: Seeing Paris In 5 Boroughs Of New York

title: Nat Finkelstein, 76, House Photographer for Warhol

body: Lemon Andersen says the word ''drive'' as if it were holy. Of course he doesn't mean it in the sense of what people do in cars or on golf courses. ''Drive,'' a noun that stuck and grew in Mr. Andersen's mind when he heard it uttered by a demanding teacher in a children's ballet class, means ambition, discipline and ruling passion. It is a force
title: THEATER REVIEW | 'COUNTY OF KINGS'; His Streets, His Stories, His Life

Both automobiles careened into a third vehicle, an unoccupied Chevrolet van, that was parked near the intersection where
title: Man Accused of D.W.I. in Fatal Crash in Brooklyn

But Mr. Newell remembers how the last time his brother lived on his own, he stopped taking his epilepsy medication and slipped on the ice,
title: For Families of Mentally Ill, Mixed Feelings Over Push Away From Adult Homes

body: HALLOWEEN AT THE A-SCARIUM Many Halloween celebrations focus on frightening creatures that travel by air: wayward spirits, witches on broomsticks, vampires disguised as bats. body: In the early evening of May 27, 1911, an electric light fell into hot tar and exploded on the Dreamland amusement pier at Coney Island. Overnight, the pier's ornate white buildings, restaurants, thrill rides, ballroom and tents -- which attracted 40,000 people a day -- were vaporized in the ensuing fire, said Charles Denson, a Coney Island
title: After 98 Years Underwater, a Coney Island Bell Is Back

body: LIKE many intensely fought-over stretches of turf (parts of Belfast come to mind), the area next to the laundry room at 755 West End Avenue was remarkably nondescript. title: The Ruckus Room

title: CONEY ISLAND JOURNAL; Bard, Boardwalk and, With Luck, Only a Staged Tempest

body: Poor Muammar el-Qaddafi. He has been trying to pitch his tent all over the New York area. title: Still No Place in New York For Qaddafi to Pitch a Tent

body: Opening this Week MERCAT NEGRE Here's a geography lesson. Mercat, the parent restaurant in Manhattan, focuses on the city of Barcelona, but with the owner Jaime Reixach's new place, opening on Sept. 24, he not only moves out to Brooklyn, but also moves out of Barcelona, giving the Catalan cuisine the rusticity of the Girona area to the northeast.

body: The New York Aquarium is moving ahead with a $100 million plan to renovate its building in Coney Island and create two massive tanks for more than 30 sharks -- about four times as many as now ply the aquarium's waters. The aquarium's ambitious plan comes even as the Bloomberg administration remains locked in tense negotiations with a major
title: Aquarium to Renovate With Giant Shark Tanks

body: DEAR DIARY: My girlfriend and I were walking to brunch in Brooklyn Heights on a July Sunday when we noticed a lemonade stand on Hicks Street. Two young girls, dressed in princess outfits, stood behind a small table as their father placed a tray of brownies next to the pitcher of lemonade. As we passed, we heard him offer timely words of advice to
title: Metropolitan Diary

body: A few hours before dawn, when most New Yorkers are fast asleep, a middle-aged man rolls out of bed in Brooklyn, dons a billowy red outfit and matching turban, climbs into his Lincoln Town Car, drives 15 minutes, pulls out a big drum and -- there on the sidewalk of a residential neighborhood -- starts to play. The man, Mohammad Boota, is a Ramadan
title: Awakening Brooklyn for Ramadan, With a Big Drum, at 4 A.M.

body: A young man's long and fraught history with an ex-girlfriend came to a violent end in Brooklyn on Saturday, when he was fatally shot by the police after an all-day siege that began with a kidnapping, the police said. The police said officers shot Samuel White, 20, when he lunged at them with a knife in his small, second-floor apartment at 607
title: Brooklyn Man Is Shot to Death by Police in Standoff

body: Sylvia Schur, a food editor who through her pioneering consulting company developed products like Clamato and Cran-Apple juice and Metrecal, wrote recipes for the fictional home chefs Ann Page and Betty Crocker and helped conceive the menus for restaurants like the Four Seasons in Manhattan, died Wednesday in Chicago. title: Sylvia Schur, Food Editor, Dies at 92; Developed Cran-Apple and Metrecal

body: Since their inaugural season in 2001, the Brooklyn Cyclones have been a remarkable success story: locals have embraced the minor league club for returning baseball to the borough after a nearly half-century absence, as overflow crowds have poured into the Coney Island ballpark year after year. title: Despite Success, Fewer Fans Cheer Cyclones

body: Many New Yorkers who are lucky enough to gaze at waves lapping on a beach near their homes pay a price for the view. Maps provided by the city's Department of Buildings show that coastal sections of Queens, Staten Island and Brooklyn are in ''special flood hazard areas.'' Practically all of Coney Island, much of the Rockaways, the Long Island
title: New York City: Few Surprises About Flood Threat

body: MARITIME FESTIVAL New York is a city of vehicles: just try to get a parking space. But long before it became famous for horn-blowing cars, careering taxis and crawling buses, it was renowned for a form of transportation that didn't even use roads, at least not those made of pavement. ''So much of New York's history is maritime history,'' said Betsy
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: Akituusaq, a 2-year-old Pacific walrus that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg once said ''melted the hearts of millions,'' died on Tuesday of complications from pneumonia, the New York Aquarium, the walrus's birthplace and home, announced on Wednesday. He was the 10th walrus born in captivity in North America since 1968, and the first born at the
title: Mourning a Beloved Walrus

body: THE cotton-candy-taffy gelato was Coney Island in a cone. Its surface was a mosaic of pink, orange, turquoise and purple, like crushed candy hearts. It left me headachy and dehydrated. title: $25 AND UNDER; 87 Scoops Later, a Sweet Meltdown

title: Beach Clubs Recall the Past, But Their Future Looks Uncertain

title: Spare Times: For Children

body: ANGER 'POSTED' The Age-Old Way Robert Keith doesn't tweet. He doesn't blog. He doesn't post comments on the Web. Mr. Keith, 75, prefers a distinctly lo-fi medium: the window poster. title: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.

author: Martha Schwendener is a freelance writer based in Brooklyn.
body: The Dutch controlled Manhattan for only a few decades before the British took over in 1664, but their influence has lingered for centuries. After all, the Netherlands in the 17th century was a cultural melting pot, and the Dutch policy of liberalism, in trade as well as religion, has been seen as a fundamental reason for New York's cosmopolitanism
title: ART REVIEW | 'DUTCH SEEN'; Photographic Links to Golden Age of Dutch Painting

title: VOWS; Julie Chang and Matt Murphy

body: 'CLICK, CLACK, MOO' According to a favorite theory in popular culture, if you give monkeys typewriters, one will eventually produce a work by Shakespeare. title: Spare Times: For Children

title: Council Approves a Proposal To Redevelop Coney Island

body: IN September 1909, during his only trip to America, Sigmund Freud visited Coney Island. title: The Case of Sigmund F. and Coney I.

body: 'THE LITTLE HOUSE OF COOKIES' Doors often seem to have their own personalities: warm, welcoming and expansive, or rigid, forbidding and impenetrable. title: Spare Times

body: DEAR DIARY: While perusing Craigslist recently in search of a sublet in my old Yorkville neighborhood near Carl Schurz Park, I came across a listing. title: Metropolitan Diary

body: THE Tesla Roadster was made for California. The all-electric convertible sports car accelerates about as fast as a Porsche 911 Turbo, but gets nearly three times the mileage equivalent of a Toyota Prius. title: Taking a Tesla for a Status Check in New York

body: An apricot that delivers a mouthful of honeyed richness is a summer treasure. It's a trifle less rare now that John Driver, a California grower, has enough Candycots to sell commercially. title: FOOD STUFF; Candy Disguised as an Apricot? How Original

body: New York City is well-known for dense skyscrapers and gritty neighborhoods, but it also has 578 miles of coastline. title: SNAPSHOT |COASTLINE; Sand, Surf and Shoobies

body: Despite his nickname, Short Al stood tall in the pantheon of overnight callers to talk shows on the New York sports radio station WFAN-AM. title: Holiday Plans? Senators Will Be Stuck in Albany

body: WEINMAN--Dorothy, on June 29, 2009. Beloved wife of the late Philip. Loving mother of Linda and mother-in-law of Michael Goldstein. Cherished grandmother of Jonathan. Devoted sister of Robert Jaffe and the late Sidney Jaffe. Service 10am Wednesday, July 1, 2009 at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel Inc., 1283 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn (Ave. J).
title: Paid Notice: Deaths WEINMAN, DOROTHY

body: In the inaugural season for the new ballparks for the New York Yankees and Mets, the teams have been embarrassed by television shots showing vast areas of premium seats going unsold. But those who study sporting facilities say empty seats may become even more commonplace here, as New York faces a glut of sports arenas. Five major complexes -- four
title: As Arenas Sprout, a Scramble to Keep Them Filled

body: ALL seemed right on this misty Thursday evening. The rain was holding up, and at Studio Square, a sleek 21st-century German beer garden near Kaufman Astoria Studios in Queens, the reggae-funk band was setting up outdoors, where people could sway to the rhythms from a field of picnic tables or multiple covered bars. I stepped up to order a Pilsner
title: THE POUR; A Beer, Please, and a (Good) Menu

author: This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
body: Mermaids Of the Deep Children longing to see a mermaid frolic in New York waters won't have to persuade their parents to buy Broadway tickets, at least not this weekend. Coney Island will offer far less expensive mermaid adventures, and none involve Disney. These come from the New York Aquarium, whose third annual Mermaids of the Deep festival is
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: BICYCLE FILM FESTIVAL Fans of fixies, alley cats, low riders and classic cruisers will turn out in droves and have their rides valet-parked this weekend for the Bicycle Film Festival, which is dedicated to celebrating the culture of the two-wheeler in all its incarnations. Since it started nine years ago, the festival, above in 2006, has expanded
title: Spare Times

body: Port Authority Produce Starting June 18, commuters dashing through the Port Authority bus terminal between 8 a.m. and 6 p.m. might be tempted to pause and pick up fresh fruits and veggies from a new indoor Greenmarket that has been installed in the terminal on the 42nd Street side. Two farms are now taking part. It will run on Thursdays year round.
title: Calendar

body: FOR CHILDREN 'ADVENTURES WITH DORA AND DIEGO' (Friday through Sunday, and Tuesday through Thursday) The young Latino stars of the Nickelodeon animated television series ''Dora the Explorer'' and ''Go, Diego, Go!'' have taken their expeditions into new territory at the Children's Museum of Manhattan, whose exhibition has separate Dora and Diego
title: SPARE TIMES | For Children

body: Pour, Sip, Discuss Rieslings from Germany, Alsace and Austria can be sampled on June 10 at Tribeca Rooftop, 2 Desbrosses Street (Hudson Street), from 6 to 9 p.m. Tickets, $40: ticketweb.com. A free tasting of 16 rosés will be held at Crush Wine, 153 East 57th Street, June 11 from 5 to 6 p.m.: events@crushwineco.com. Birthday Dinner The Depuy Canal
title: Calendar

body: Swimmers were told to stay out of the water on Sunday at Coney Island and nearby Manhattan Beach because of concerns about a sewage overflow. The city's parks department posted signs Sunday saying swimming was not permitted at the two Brooklyn beaches. But the Coney Island boardwalk was open, and sunbathing on the sand was allowed. The city's
title: Sewage Worries Close 2 Brooklyn Beaches

body: A Greek diner that closed over the weekend after serving as a late-night refuge for patients and staff at Bellevue Hospital Center since 1984 will be able to reopen, and will not be supplanted by an Au Bon Pain, as some had feared. The city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, which runs Bellevue, reached an agreement Tuesday night with the family
title: Au Bon Pain Won't Unseat Greek Diner At Bellevue

body: JAPAN DAY In Japan no occasion is too small to warrant a gift. A visit to a friend, the signing of a lease or a return from a short trip is accompanied by a small token or simple cash. So it is no surprise that in 1912 the Japanese saw fit to send cherry trees to cities in the United States, including New York, where some took root in Central Park.
title: SPARE TIMES

body: A job fair for Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus may conjure visions of strapping gymnasts in spandex, carnival barkers and more clowns than you can fit in a small car. But the 150 positions being offered at KeySpan Park in Coney Island on Wednesday were for far less fanciful jobs. Ringling Brothers is preparing for its first extended
title: At Circus Job Fair, No Thrill Seekers Needed

body: KURZMAN--Kala Ruth, 77, of Brooklyn passed away peacefully after a long illness of cancer. She was predeceased by her parents, Benjamin and Sarah Kurzman. She is survived by her brother Herbert of Monroe Twp., NJ and many relatives and friends. A funeral service will be held at Weinstein-Garlick-Kirschenbaum Chapels, 1153 Coney Island Ave.,
title: Paid Notice: Deaths KURZMAN, KALA RUTH

body: SALKIN--Goldie, of Boca Raton, Florida originally of Brooklyn, NY died on May 25th, 2009. After struggling with numerous ailments, she passed serenely and peacefully at Hospice by the Sea surrounded by her loving family. Goldie was our matriarch, and is survived by her adoring husband of 62 years Ben, her children Bruce, Ellen, Ellyn, Bob, Susan
title: Paid Notice: Deaths SALKIN, GOLDIE

body: The Bloomberg administration has a grand vision to preserve what's left of Coney Island's historic character as a rollicking amusement park, but a century ago, right around the Memorial Day weekend, the mayor ordered the police to close the attractions at the seaside resort on Sundays as a public nuisance. At issue in May 1909 was whether new blue
title: Coney Island Beat Censors By Wearing Cap and Gown

body: BUS-STOP TALKS For a Libretto The Allison aria will get written one of these days. The clock is ticking. The world premiere is scheduled for May 22. But first, the librettist had to get married. ''Just one more thing to check off the to-do list,'' said the librettist, Dawn Weleski, whose wedding was in Pittsburgh on Friday. Other items on the list
title: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.

His professional career included writer, neuro-surgeon, educator and Managed Care and Pharmaceutical Executive Medical Director. He graduated from Hofstra University, NY 1975 and
title: Paid Notice: Deaths LEHMAN, LAWRENCE BRAD, M.D.

body: EVEN in the best of conditions, swimming long distances in unfamiliar water is an exercise in mild disorientation. Add waves, strong currents and the chilly seas that persist into the spring, and the voices in your head that say you're crazy grow even louder. A partial antidote, Gilles Chalandon was saying the other day, is to have landmarks on the
title: DISPATCHES; On a Beach In Brooklyn, A Chair Sits Empty

body: Alabama CITY STAGES Birmingham, June 19-21. This eclectic festival, which invades downtown for three days every summer, is comprised of a seemingly random selection of gospel, hip-hop, jazz, folk and rock 'n' roll acts, including Jane's Addiction, Young Jeezy, Indigo Girls, Charlie Wilson, the Neville Brothers, En Vogue, the Doobie Brothers, Guster
title: Summer Stages: Pop/Jazz

body: IN September, New Yorkers will celebrate the quadricentennial of Henry Hudson's voyage, and if you ever wondered what Hudson encountered when he arrived, you can turn for answers to Eric W. Sanderson, who reimagines 1609 Manhattan in stunning and exuberant detail. Mr. Sanderson, a senior ecologist at the Wildlife Conservation Society, has
title: READING NEW YORK; Tours,Tycoons and Crazy Joe

body: JEAN GEORGES, the flagship of the chef Jean-Georges Vongerichten, won the James Beard Foundation's outstanding restaurant award Monday night and Drew Nieporent, a partner in Nobu and Corton in TriBeCa, was named outstanding restaurateur. Dan Barber of Blue Hill in Greenwich Village and Blue Hill at Stone Barns in Westchester County won the
title: James Beard Awards

body: DURING almost 30 years as a director, Tony Scott has worked with more than his share of movie juggernauts, like Tom Cruise (''Top Gun'') and Brad Pitt (''Spy Game'') and Dennis Hopper (''True Romance''). More than a year ago, down on the tracks inside a dark, disorienting stretch of subway tunnel in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn, he had his
title: Manhattan Transfer: Remaking 'Pelham'

body: Jessica Lappin, a first-term city councilwoman from the Upper East Side of Manhattan, has been known to answer the phone singing the fight song: ''Meet the Mets, meet the Mets, step right up and greet the Mets!'' Councilman James Oddo of Staten Island becomes Facebook friends with minor-league players so he knows about them if they are drafted by
title: In Council, It's Mets 18, Yanks 13, and Neither 12

body: Though the Phish shows that will open this summer's season at the Nikon at Jones Beach Theater are already sold out, the Wantagh, N.Y., performance space will offer plenty of other opportunities to rock out. The promoter Live Nation announced the rest of the theater's summer shows, which include the country artists Kenny Chesney, above, Miranda
title: ARTS, BRIEFLY; Summer Concerts In New York Area

body: SPOKES: WHERE Racing Lives On It has been more than a half-century since New Yorkers last flocked in great numbers to see cyclists tear around banked velodrome tracks at the center of Manhattan. Easy to forget, then, that Madison Square Garden, in its earlier incarnation off 26th Street and Madison Avenue, played host to major races watched by tens
title: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.

body: ORLECK--Thelma. January 18, 1917-April 26, 2009, 92, died peacefully in her home in Thetford Center, Vermont, with her children and grandchildren close to her. The daughter of Harry Hershenson and Anna Alper, she was born in Brooklyn, New York in 1917 where she lived for most of her life. On June 12, 1938 she married Norman Orleck with whom she
title: Paid Notice: Deaths ORLECK, THELMA

body: The mound of salt in the Red Hook Marine Terminal soars over the waterfront, as white and dry as the sands of Coney Island and as tall as the four-story brick tenements across the street. Salt piles, while not common, have been seen over the years in the neighborhood, which is on the border, roughly, of Red Hook and Cobble Hill. But residents said
title: Now Growing in Brooklyn, A Waterfront Pile of Salt

body: O.K., the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus already came to town last month with considerable fanfare. Now, it will be arriving yet again, trading a Manhattan arena for a seaside tent in Coney Island. In a news conference on Friday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced that Ringling's touring show -- called the Gold Unit by the circus,
title: Ringling Circus To Raise a Tent In Coney Island

body: Open Now EMPORIO Fitting its name, there are a few shelves of provisions for sale in this casual restaurant, which has replaced In Tent. The menu of Riccardo Buitoni, left, takes its cue from Rome, with fried artichokes, garganelli in Amatrice sauce, tonnarelli cacio e pepe, and Frascati-braised rabbit with rosemary: 231 Mott Street (Prince
title: Off the Menu

body: WHEN it comes to the recession, tactful New Yorkers may refrain from complaining too loudly about their misfortunes, knowing that the chances are, there is someone else out there who has it worse. But try explaining to a 6-year-old, no matter how worldly and well mannered, that budget cuts may prevent him from spending quality time with a penguin.
title: CONEY ISLAND; A Small Casualty In Hard Times

body: It was John Strong III who threw down the gauntlet in the latest Coney Island showdown. ''Dick Zigun and his Coney Island Circus Sideshow had better hold onto their hats, because we're bringing the weirdest, most bizarre, outlandish and strangest collection of freaks and oddballs that the People's Playground has ever seen,'' said Mr. Strong, a
title: Beyond Sideshows, the City and a Developer Face Off Over Coney Island's Future

body: A humpback whale was spotted for several hours Thursday in New York Harbor near the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, the Coast Guard said. The whale, which was first reported to the authorities by a resident's phone call around 8 a.m., did not appear to be injured or entangled. ''It's going out toward the ocean,'' said Petty Officer David Schulein, a
title: Humpback Whale Visits New York Harbor, Protected by Coast Guard

body: 9 P.M. (13); 10 P.M. (49) GLASS: A PORTRAIT OF PHILIP IN 12 PARTS In 2005 Scott Hicks begin filming the composer Philip Glass, left, in honor of his 70th birthday, in 2007. For 18 months Mr. Hicks followed Mr. Glass across three continents -- from his annual ride on the Coney Island Cyclone to the premiere of his opera ''Waiting for the
title: What's On Today

body: I own a fairly large vintage sign that sits imposingly on my living room floor. It once hung outside a place called Velulich's Bakery, somewhere in New Jersey, and is typical of the painted metal displays of the 1930s, with Art Deco contours and neon illumination. It's as beautiful as the hand-painted shoe-repair sign I keep in my bedroom. Both are
title: VISUALS; Signs and Portents

author: Alex Rose is the author of ''The Musical Illusionist and Other Tales,'' a collection of short fiction.
body: AT the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and 59th Street sits the Plaza, with its spiky stone finials and sea-green roof moldings. Across the street, a path cuts into the sprawl of Central Park. Uniformed carriage drivers stand by their horses, awaiting sightseers. Underground, the R train rumbles away. Even people who have never set foot in the
title: New York Vérité (Sort of)

body: After years of offering bulk discounts and pregame parades on the field to local youth baseball groups, the Mets have so far benched the promotions at their new $800 million Citi Field stadium in Queens, according to youth baseball officials. ''I'm getting a lot of feedback from parents -- they're upset,'' said Bob Reid, president of the Bayside
title: For Many Little Leaguers At Citi Field, a Little Less

body: Coney Island was looking pretty good for being dead. A new gear had been put on the Wonder Wheel. The sun licked at the windows of the Freak Bar. There was the smell of fresh-laid paint. But the condolence calls kept coming: disbelief from Boston, despondency from London. Friends came by on maudlin visits. Ferris wheel lovers sent their deep
title: CONEY ISLAND JOURNAL; It's Alive! Step Right Up and See for Yourself!

body: SLIDESHOW: PADDLING THROUGH HISTORY The rivers in the Dordogne region of southwestern France have invited exploration and settlement since the days of the Neanderthals. Today the scenic landscape still harbors hundreds of caves containing prehistoric creations, as well as remnants of more recent history. nytimes.com/travel SLIDESHOW: HIKING THE
title: ON NYTIMES.COM

body: Here's the plan. We drop whatever humdrum thing we're doing and leave for Washington. Right away is not too soon. Once there, we head straight to the National Museum of African Art and begin our descent into the galleries, down being the only direction for this subterranean branch of the Smithsonian. As it turns out, we aren't going underground.
title: ART REVIEW | 'MAMI WATA'; From the Deep, a Diva With Many Faces

body: CITY OFFERS TO BUY Coney Island Land Less than 24 hours before a City Council hearing Wednesday on the city's redevelopment plans for Coney Island, the Bloomberg administration offered to pay $105 million for roughly 10 acres owned by a developer with a rival plan for amusements, hotels, housing and shops. The offer, delivered by letter to the
title: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.

body: NEW YORK DAYBOOK Men, Skirts and a Cause Monday, 7:30 p.m. The Male Unbifurcated Garment movement began in the early 1990s when a cross-dressing Swede named Roger Lewau launched a now-defunct Web site called the Skirts Lover Nest. Over the years, the movement has strived for civil rights in displays of pride that have included a march down Fifth
title: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.

body: POP Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. AKRON/FAMILY (Friday through Sunday) This trio's scrap-folk is built on the oxymoronic notion of tough fragility, and listening to it feels a little bit like driving a pickup with three good wheels: hold on tight and hope everything sticks together. For the concert, expect an entrancing
title: The Listings

author: Mathew R. Warren contributed reporting.
body: A home health aide was horrified after her middle finger was cut off at the tip. A firefighter lost part of his finger, too. A woman bumped her head as she was knocked to the floor. A man was left with a swollen hand and broken eyeglasses, someone else a broken nose, someone else two missing toes. Tenants who live in New York City public housing
title: Records Show the Physical Toll Of Public Housing's Elevators

body: NANCY AND AZIZ LAMAZOU hail from Lebanon and Tunisia. During Mr. Lamazou's years as a diplomat, they ate their way across the globe. They're purveyors of fine European packaged goods. They cave continental cheeses beneath a New York City sidewalk. They sell carefully made sandwiches. Nicky Defonte, born and raised in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, is the
title: $25 AND UNDER; Within Six Blocks, Worlds Apart

body: The same scene of heartbreak played out over and over on Sunday on a ragtag patch of Neptune Avenue in Coney Island, where the word ''scrappy'' may be better suited to describe the metal in the auto shops than any sort of community spirit. Since 1924, Totonno's pizzeria has been a beacon on the block, remarkable for its longevity, for the
title: Fire Shuts Totonno's, Legendary Coney Island Pizzeria

body: Angela Wu Cen, 19, knew many details about her parents' 13-year migration from China to Panama to New York. But she had never known much about a more intimate aspect of her parents' lives: their courtship. So when Ms. Wu, who was born in Panama and was 12 when the family came to the United States, sat down to interview her mother for an honors
title: Family Stories As Secret Text For Immigrants

body: CHARNEY--Seth Dragiff, M.D.,64, died peacefully at home on March 8, 2009 in San Francisco, CA. Devoted son of teh late Morris and Nettie Charney. Survived by his beloved siblings, Dr. Jonathan Charney and Dr. Maria Diaz and by Deborah Braff and Dr. Robert Braff. Loving uncle of Samuel Charney, Aaron Charney, Danielle Braff Karpinos and Vadim
title: Paid Notice: Deaths CHARNEY, SETH DRAGIFF, M.D.

body: NEW YORK DAYBOOK If Edison's Your Idol ... Monday, 6:30 p.m. A cynic might suggest that an inventors' conference at a Holiday Inn is about as incongruous as a superhero forum at a truck stop -- a noble enterprise diminished by location. Then again, all cannot be wrong with the world if tomorrow's Edisons are actually meeting. The Inventors
title: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.; New York Daybook

author: E-mail: susan.dominus@nytimes.com
body: If you managed to get out of the house without glimpsing the news over the weekend, you might, for a few hours at least, have allowed yourself to indulge in a bit of luxurious, sun-baked optimism. The snowstorm of last week, all those inches, all those glitches, the piles of snow whiting out plans and best intentions, seemed like a vicious weather
title: BIG CITY; Sunshine Is Harbinger Of Optimism

Ruby lived a life devoted to his wife, his children, Harry and Leon, his daughters in law, Myra and Marsha, and his grandchildren Elliot, Lauren,

body: IN scene after scene in ''Two Lovers,'' the new movie starring Gwyneth Paltrow and Joaquin Phoenix as a star-crossed couple, the Brooklyn neighborhood of Brighton Beach is on lush display. The camera lingers affectionately on Brighton Cleaners on Coney Island Avenue, on Cafe Restaurant Volna, which sits opposite the Boardwalk, and on the Boardwalk
title: BRIGHTON BEACH; Brighton Beach, N.J.

body: IT had been 38 years since William Friedkin last trained a camera on the boxy red-brick apartment complex on Stillwell Avenue, just a few blocks north of the Coney Island boardwalk in Brooklyn. But on a bright, windy day last spring, Mr. Friedkin was back with a crew -- shooting high-definition video this time -- to revisit the fictional residence
title: FILM; Filmmaking at 90 Miles Per Hour

body: Rusty Kanokogi learned to scrap when her name was still Rena Glickman and she wandered the Brooklyn boardwalk. She learned to struggle when her parents ignored her in a tiny house near Coney Island. She learned to attack when she discovered judo in a dojo on Flatbush Avenue. She learned to argue in plush offices when she lobbied for women's judo to
title: Fighter for Her Sport Has Own Battle

body: Last June, Bakht Bilind Khan, who was living in the Bronx and working at a fast-food restaurant, returned to his village in the volatile Swat Valley of northern Pakistan to visit his wife and seven children for the first time in three years. But at a dinner celebration with his family, his homecoming suddenly turned dark: several heavily armed
title: From a Pakistan Valley, Taliban Threats Are Heard in New York

body: A few minutes after 6 a.m. Wednesday, the driver of a black sport utility vehicle called 911 from his cellphone to report that he had just hit someone on 108th Street in Corona, Queens. He went back to the spot. But there was no body there. At 7:05 a.m. in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, the driver of a red van noticed a pedestrian trying to flag him
title: Queens Driver Unknowingly Drags a Body Nearly 20 Miles

body: The M/V North River, a twin-screw tanker out of Brooklyn, steamed past Rikers Island, swung to port, then slipped into its mooring in Hunts Point, in the Bronx. A deckhand tied the ship off while another hooked its hoses to a manifold. Above decks, in the bridge, the first mate took the signal, then gently depressed a switch. With a hum of quiet
title: ROOMS; Where the Sea Air Meets Its Match

body: Afreen Juli, a senior at the Bronx High School of Science, applied early to Cooper Union, a college in Manhattan that specializes in engineering, art and architecture. So did 10 of her classmates, the most ever from Bronx Science, one of the city's most selective public schools. Ms. Juli, who lives in Coney Island, said that she wanted to study
title: Free College Has Allure Heightened By Economy

body: Hey, Alabama, you want a piece of us? Olde New York, that is. Now that an Alabama couple have purchased the Cheyenne Diner on Ninth Avenue and 33rd Street, they say they are eyeing the historic Ridgewood Theater in Queens, which played movies from 1916 until it closed last year. La Barge, Wyo., snared an even more revered restaurant, the Moondance
title: When Diners Pick Up Stakes, And Vintage New York Is Lost

body: To the Editor: Re ''Minding Coney Island'' (editorial, Feb. 4): Coney Island is not only a world-famous amusement district; it is on one of the most beautiful beaches in the Northeast. For historical as well as environmental reasons, we strongly support your position of disallowing hotels or any high rises on the beach side -- the south side of
title: LETTER; Coney Island Development

body: The Mets said Thursday that despite the prominence of the principal owner, Fred Wilpon, his family and his businesses on a 162-page list of the victims of Bernard L. Madoff's suspected $50 billion Ponzi scheme, the team remains financially sound. ''As we have said before on numerous occasions, this does not and will not affect the day-to-day
title: Mets Are Prominent On the Madoff List, But Say They're Fine

body: Lawrence Ferlinghetti once wrote that Coney Island is ''where I first fell in love with unreality.'' Today, a desolate reality has taken hold at the legendary amusement park. As rides close, bulldozers uproot land that once held delightfully sinister sideshows. The few rides left barely lure neighborhood children and nostalgic tourists. Mayor
title: EDITORIAL; Minding Coney Island

body: The latest development dispute in Dumbo involves a proposal that has, for many residents, tinges of a Faustian bargain. Many among them want a local middle school for their children. But they are not sure they want it badly enough to accept its proposed packaging -- an apartment tower that would block views of their neighborhood's most prized
title: Wondering if a New School in Brooklyn Is Worth Blocking a View of the Bridge

body: They sat in a Volvo parked at the beach, cupping their numb hands over the vents blasting hot air. With icy water still sitting in droplets on their bright pink skin, they hunched over in silence, teeth chattering and shoulders twitching. It was the middle of January, and Rachel Golub and Cristian Vergara had just gone for a dip in the Atlantic.
title: Icy Ritual in Brooklyn, Training for a Challenge

body: REAL ESTATE PARTY With Somber Tone Bone-chilling temperatures, news of a plane crash and endless worries about the economy didn't stop members of New York City's real estate world from donning their tuxedos for one of their favorite annual events. They headed to the New York Hilton on Thursday for the 113th annual Real Estate Board of New York
title: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.

body: EVEN if the latest economic slump stunts the explosion of New York's population before the end of the decade, you can count on the fact that the city's proverbial changing neighborhoods will keep changing. Detailed census figures released last month and analyzed for The New York Times by Andrew Beveridge, chairman of the sociology department at
title: NEW YORK BY THE NUMBERS; Neighborhoods, Up Close and Personal

body: In the 17 years ''The Real World'' has been appearing on MTV, it has deployed the services of 400 editors to scan 40,000 hours of film. As Jon Murray, one of the executive producers, explains in ''The Real World: Secrets Revealed,'' a special being shown this week anticipating the new season's start on Wednesday, this progenitor of reality
title: TELEVISION REVIEW | 'THE REAL WORLD'; The Show That Put the 'Real' in Reality TV

body: ''I'M really a modernist,'' said Serine Hastings, who lived in prewar apartments her first three decades in New York. Since moving from Chicago in the late 1970s, she has always made her home in places with vintage architectural details. ''I lived on the top floor of a Federal town house in Chelsea and a co-op on the Upper West Side,'' said Ms.
title: HABITATS | BOERUM HILL, BROOKLYN; After All Those Brownstones, a Blank Canvas

body: A 61-year-old livery-cab driver was shot and killed while working in Coney Island, Brooklyn, on Wednesday morning, the police said. It is believed to be the first killing of an on-duty livery driver since 2006, said Fernando A. Mateo, the spokesman for the New York State Federation of Taxi Drivers, which says it has about 22,000 members, including
title: Cabbie Is Shot to Death On Duty in Coney Island
